lines.text: [Emma has just recounted her story to her cellmate, ending with her learning of Nelson's death]
And then?
Then what?
What happened after?
There is no "then". There is no "after".
What are those bells?
Have you forgotten what night this is? Last of 1799; eight bells for the old year, and eight for the new. Happy New Year, darling.
Happy New Year.
The dawn of a new century.
1800. How strange it sounds.
Marlborough rode to war, and Washington crossed the Delaware. Louis XVI, and Marie Antoinette. The last of the Stuarts. Peter the Great. Voltaire. Clive of India. Bonaparte...
...Nelson.

...and I forgot London, and the old ways. I was young. I healed quickly. I learned French and Italian, music and dancing. And one day, I had more than I ever dreamed of. I became his wife... Emma, Lady Hamilton.

[shocked after seeing Lord Nelson's wounds]
They told us of your victories but not of the price you paid!

[Greeting a lady in waiting for the Queen of Naples]
Good morning, your ladyship. My daughter, her ladyship, is still resting. And how is Her Majesty's sore throat? You know the best thing for a sore throat is to wrap a woolen sock around your neck before bed.
Good morning, your ladyship.
[to Emma's mother]
Is Emma still asleep?
She is asleep. In my village, a husband just turns round in bed to look for himself.
Yes, and the Queen of Naples does not wear woolen socks!

Gentlemen, you will never make peace with Napoleon! Napoleon cannot be master of the world until he has smashed us up, and believe me, gentlemen, he means to be master of the world! You cannot make peace with dictators. You have to destroy them, wipe them out!
